'''The Goldman Sachs Group, Inc.''' ({{IPAc-en|s|æ|k|s}} {{respell|SAKS}}) is an American multinational [[Investment banking|investment bank]]<!-- Its investment banking arm is a separate institution to its financial services. They are separate components that add up to the diversified services of the company. Leave as "investment bank and financial services company".--> and [[financial services]] company. Founded in 1869, Goldman Sachs is headquartered in [[Lower Manhattan]] in [[New York City]], with regional [[headquarters]] in many international financial centers.<ref name="AR"/> Goldman Sachs is the [[list of investment banks|second largest investment bank]] in the world by revenue<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.statista.com/statistics/371143/leading-global-investment-banks-by-revenue/ |title=Leading banks worldwide, by revenue from investment banking |website=[[Statista]] |url-status=live |access-date=March 29, 2018 |archive-date=March 30, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180330143459/https://www.statista.com/statistics/371143/leading-global-investment-banks-by-revenue/ }}</ref> and is ranked 55th on the [[Fortune 500|''Fortune'' 500]] list of the largest United States corporations by total revenue.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://fortune.com/company/goldman-sachs-group/fortune500/ | title=Fortune 500 Companies: Goldman Sachs | publisher=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] | url-status=live | access-date=January 17, 2022 | archive-date=June 2, 2020 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200602130619/https://fortune.com/company/goldman-sachs-group/fortune500/ }}</ref> It is considered a [[systemically important financial institution]] by the [[Financial Stability Board]].

Goldman Sachs offers services in [[investment banking]] (advisory for [[mergers and acquisitions]] and [[restructuring]]), [[securities underwriting]], [[prime brokerage]], [[asset management]] as well as [[wealth management]] and [[investment management]] via [[Goldman Sachs Personal Financial Management]]. It is a [[market maker]] for many types of financial products and provides [[clearing (finance)|clearing]] and [[custodian bank]] services. It operates [[private-equity fund]]s and [[hedge fund]]s. It structures complex and tailor-made financial products. It also owns Goldman Sachs Bank USA, a [[direct bank]]. It trades both on behalf of its clients ([[flow trading]]) and for its own account ([[proprietary trading]]). The company invests in and arranges financing for startups, and in many cases gets additional business as [[bookrunner]] when the companies launch [[initial public offering]]s.<ref>{{Cite news | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/goldman-sachs-wants-to-charm-startups-it-wont-be-easy-11621515741 | title=Goldman Sachs Wants to Charm Startups. It Won't Be Easy. | first=Peter | last=Rudegeair | work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | date=May 20, 2021 | url-access=subscription | access-date=January 23, 2022 | archive-date=January 23, 2022 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220123052529/https://www.wsj.com/articles/goldman-sachs-wants-to-charm-startups-it-wont-be-easy-11621515741 | url-status=live }}</ref> It is one of over 100 strategic partners of the [[World Economic Forum]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Goldman Sachs |url=https://www.weforum.org/organizations/the-goldman-sachs-group-inc/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220723124154/https://www.weforum.org/organizations/the-goldman-sachs-group-inc |archive-date=July 23, 2022 |access-date=September 17, 2022 |website=[[World Economic Forum]] |language=en}}</ref>

==History==
===Founding and establishment===
{{See also|Goldman–Sachs family}}
In 1869, Goldman Sachs was founded by [[Marcus Goldman]] in New York City in a one-room basement office next to a coal chute.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.thestar.com.my/business/business-news/2020/12/09/insight---core-goldman-sachs-wont-flee-new-york-for-florida | title=Insight - Core Goldman Sachs won't flee New York for Florida | first=BRIAN | last=CHAPPATTA | work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] | date=December 9, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news | url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/business/ct-goldman-sachs-mystique-20161215-story.html | title=The eternal mystique of Goldman Sachs | first=Dan | last=Zack | agency=[[The Washington Post]] | work=[[Chicago Tribune]] | date=December 15, 2016 | url-access=limited}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/1997-12-21/inside-the-money-machine | first1=Leah Nathans | last1=Spiro | first2=Stanley | last2=Reed | title=Inside the Money Machine-In a big-is-all business, Goldman vows to go it alone  | publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.]] | date=December 22, 1997 | url-access=subscription | archive-date=August 27, 2020 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200827190404/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/1997-12-21/inside-the-money-machine | url-status=live }}</ref> In 1882, Goldman's son-in-law [[Samuel Sachs]] joined the firm.<ref>{{cite news | title=Business & Finance: Cash & Comeback | url=https://content.time.com/time/subscriber/article/0,33009,770464,00.html  | magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] | date=November 9, 1936 | archive-date=October 23, 2020 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201023122152/http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,770464,00.html | url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/2010/05/21/goldman-sachs-fraud-case-personal-finance-gs.html#1b2ef41476b3|title=The Evolution Of Goldman Sachs|last=Beattie|first=Andrew|website=Forbes|language=en|access-date=February 11, 2020|archive-date=July 22, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180722160258/https://www.forbes.com/2010/05/21/goldman-sachs-fraud-case-personal-finance-gs.html#1b2ef41476b3|url-status=live}}</ref> In 1885, Goldman's son, [[Henry Goldman]], and his son-in-law, Ludwig Dreyfuss, joined the business and the firm adopted its present name, Goldman Sachs & Co.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Endlich|first=Lisa |author-link=Lisa Endlich |title=Goldman Sachs: The Culture Of Success|publisher=[[A.A. Knopf]] |location=New York |year=1999|isbn=978-0679450801|page=[https://archive.org/details/goldmansachscult00endl/page/34 34]|url=https://archive.org/details/goldmansachscult00endl/page/34}}</ref> The company pioneered the use of [[commercial paper]] for entrepreneurs and joined the [[New York Stock Exchange]] (NYSE) in 1896.<ref name="Cohan2012">{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=91XpjbCqbbcC | author=William D. Cohan | title=Money and Power: How Goldman Sachs Came to Rule the World | year=2012 | publisher=[[Penguin Random House]] | isbn=978-0241954065 | access-date=May 9, 2017 | archive-date=March 31, 2019 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190331160518/https://books.google.com/books?id=91XpjbCqbbcC | url-status=live }}</ref> By 1898, the firm's capital stood at $1.6 million.<ref name="Cohan2012"/> It opened offices in Boston and Chicago in 1900, San Francisco in 1918, and Philadelphia and St. Louis in 1920.<ref name=brief>{{Cite web |url=https://www.goldmansachs.com/our-firm/history/a-brief-history-of-gs.pdf | title=A Brief History of Goldman Sachs | work=Goldman Sachs}}</ref>

Goldman entered the [[initial public offering]] market in 1906 when it took [[Sears, Roebuck and Company]] public.<ref name="Cohan2012"/> The deal was facilitated by Henry Goldman's personal friendship with [[Julius Rosenwald]], an owner of Sears.<ref name="Cohan2012" /> Other underwriting work for initial public offerings followed, including those of [[General Cigar Company]] also in 1906, [[F. W. Woolworth Company]] in 1912, and [[Continental Can]].<ref name=brief/><ref name="Cohan2012"/> The firm was an innovator at establishing the [[price–earnings ratio]], instead of [[book value]], as a method for valuing companies, and was therefore able to raise funds for retailers and companies with few hard assets.<ref name=brief/>

In 1912, Henry S. Bowers became the first non-member of the founding family to become a partner of the company and share in its profits.<ref name="Cohan2012" />

In 1917, under growing pressure from the other partners in the firm due to his pro-German stance, Henry Goldman resigned.<ref name="Cohan2012" /> The Sachs family gained full control of the firm until [[Waddill Catchings]] joined the company in 1918.<ref name="Cohan2012" /> By 1928, Catchings was the Goldman partner with the single largest stake in the firm.<ref name="Cohan2012" /> In 1919, the company acquired a major interest in [[Merck & Co.]] and in 1922, it acquired a major interest in [[General Foods]].<ref name=brief/>

On December 4, 1928, the firm launched the Goldman Sachs Trading Corp.Ad, a [[closed-end fund]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/photo-essays/2011-07-20/goldman-sachs-the-good-the-bad-and-the-ugly |title=Goldman Sachs, the Good, the Bad, and the Ugly |work=[[Bloomberg News]] |date=July 20, 2011 | url-access=subscription | archive-date=March 31, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190331104330/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/photo-essays/2011-07-20/goldman-sachs-the-good-the-bad-and-the-ugly|url-status=live}}</ref> The fund failed during the [[Wall Street Crash of 1929]], amid accusations that Goldman had engaged in share price manipulation and [[insider trading]].<ref name="Cohan2012"/>

===1930-1980===
In 1930, during the [[Great Depression]], the firm ousted Catchings, and [[Sidney Weinberg]] assumed the role of senior partner. Weinberg shifted Goldman's focus away from trading and toward [[investment banking]].<ref name="Cohan2012"/> His actions helped to restore some of Goldman's tarnished reputation. Under Weinberg's leadership, Goldman was the lead advisor on the $657 million [[initial public offering]] of [[Ford Motor Company]] in 1956, a major victory at the time, as well as the $350 million debenture offering by Sears Roebuck in 1958.<ref name=brief/> Under Weinberg's leadership, the firm started an investment research division and a [[municipal bond]] department, and it became an early innovator in [[risk arbitrage]].<ref name="Cohan2012" />

In the 1950s, [[Gus Levy]] joined the firm as a securities trader, where two powers fought for supremacy, one from investment banking and one from securities trading. Levy was a pioneer in [[block trade|block trading]] and the firm established this trend under his guidance. Due to Weinberg's heavy influence, the firm formed an investment banking division in 1956 in an attempt to shift focus off Weinberg.<ref name="Cohan2012" />

In 1957, the company's headquarters were relocated to 20 [[Broad Street (Manhattan)|Broad Street]], New York City.<ref name="Cohan2012"/>

In 1969, Levy took over Weinberg's role as Senior Partner and built Goldman's trading franchise once again.<ref>{{Cite book |year=2000 |publisher=[[Simon & Schuster]] |last=Endlich |first=Lisa |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BDionNrrBqwC&q=1969+levy&pg=PA62 |title=Goldman Sachs: The Culture Of Success |isbn=978-0684869681 |page=62 |archive-date=June 14, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210614103756/https://books.google.com/books?id=BDionNrrBqwC&q=1969+levy&pg=PA62 |url-status=live}}</ref> Levy is credited with Goldman's famous philosophy of being "long-term greedy," which implied that as long as money is made over the long term, short-term losses are bearable. At the same time, partners reinvested nearly all of their earnings in the firm.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Endlich |first=Lisa| author-link=Lisa Endlich |title=Goldman Sachs: The Culture Of Success| publisher=[[A.A. Knopf]] |location=New York |year=1999| isbn=978-0679450801 |page=[https://archive.org/details/goldmansachscult00endl/page/18 18] |url=https://archive.org/details/goldmansachscult00endl/page/18}}</ref> Weinberg remained a senior partner of the firm and died in July of that year.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1969/07/24/archives/sidney-j-weinberg-dies-at-77-mr-wall-street-of-finance-sidney-j.html | title=Sidney J. Weinberg Dies at 77; 'Mr. Wall Street' of Finance; Sidney J. Weinberg, Known as 'Mr. Wall Street,' Is Dead at 77 | first=Alden | last=Whitman | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=July 24, 1969 | url-access=limited}}</ref>

Another financial crisis for the firm occurred in 1970, when the [[Penn Central Transportation Company]] went bankrupt with over $80 million (~${{Format price|{{Inflation|index=US-GDP|value=80000000|start_year=1970}}}} in {{Inflation/year|US-GDP}}) in [[commercial paper]] outstanding, most of it issued through Goldman Sachs. The bankruptcy was large, and the resulting lawsuits, notably by the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission|SEC]], threatened the partnership capital, survival, and reputation of the firm.<ref name="cohan_wpost2012">{{cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/goldman-sachss-long-history-of-duping-its-clients/2012/03/15/gIQAVlu3GS_story.html | title=Goldman Sachs's long history of duping its clients | last=Cohan | first=William D. | newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] | date=March 16, 2012 | url-access=limited | archive-date=November 9, 2020 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201109190908/https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/goldman-sachss-long-history-of-duping-its-clients/2012/03/15/gIQAVlu3GS_story.html | url-status=live }}</ref> It was this bankruptcy that resulted in [[credit rating]]s for every issuer of commercial paper today by several credit rating services.<ref>{{cite web | last=Hahn | first=Thomas K. | editor=Timothy Q. Cook | editor2=Robert K. Laroche | title=Instruments of the Money Market | url=https://www.richmondfed.org/~/media/richmondfedorg/publications/research/special_reports/instruments_of_the_money_market/pdf/full_publication.pdf | edition=Seventh | publisher=Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond | location=[[Richmond, Virginia]] | year=1993 | access-date=April 7, 2017 | archive-date=November 25, 2020 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201125001943/https://www.richmondfed.org/~/media/richmondfedorg/publications/research/special_reports/instruments_of_the_money_market/pdf/full_publication.pdf | url-status=live }}</ref>

Under the direction of Senior Partner Stanley R. Miller, the firm opened its first international office in London in 1970 and created a [[Private Wealth Management]] division along with a [[fixed income]] division in 1972.<ref name=brief/><ref>{{Cite news |last=Colchester |first=Max |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/who-loses-the-most-from-brexit-try-goldman-sachs-1460403274 |title=Who Loses the Most From 'Brexit'? Try Goldman Sachs |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date=April 11, 2016 |issn=0099-9660 |archive-date=November 8, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201108095658/https://www.wsj.com/articles/who-loses-the-most-from-brexit-try-goldman-sachs-1460403274|url-status=live}}</ref> It pioneered the "[[white knight (business)|white knight]]" strategy in 1974 during its attempts to defend Electric Storage Battery against a [[hostile takeover]] bid from International Nickel and Goldman's rival, [[Morgan Stanley]].<ref>{{cite book | first=Gary | last=Giroux | title=Accounting Fraud: Maneuvering and Manipulation, Past and Present | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gxNMAgAAQBAJ | publisher=Business Expert Press | isbn=978-1606496299 | date=2013 | archive-date=April 8, 2017 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170408085303/https://books.google.com/books?id=gxNMAgAAQBAJ | url-status=live }}</ref> [[John Weinberg]], the son of Sidney Weinberg, and [[John C. Whitehead]] assumed the roles of co-senior partners in 1976, once again emphasizing the co-leadership at the firm. One of their initiatives was the establishment of 14 business principles.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Thomas |first=Landon Jr. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/09/business/09weinberg.html |title=John L. Weinberg, 81, Former Leader of Goldman, Dies |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=August 9, 2006 | url-access=limited |issn=0362-4331 |archive-date=November 21, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201121075533/https://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/09/business/09weinberg.html |url-status=live}}</ref>

===1981-2000===
On November 16, 1981, the firm acquired J. Aron & Company, a [[commodities trading]] firm that merged with the Fixed Income division to become known as Fixed Income, Currencies, and Commodities.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Baer |first=Justin |title=In Wake of Financial Crisis, Goldman Goes It Alone |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/in-wake-of-financial-crisis-goldman-goes-it-alone-1423711981| date=December 12, 2015 | url-access=subscription |issn=0099-9660|archive-date=August 1, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200801042635/https://www.wsj.com/articles/in-wake-of-financial-crisis-goldman-goes-it-alone-1423711981 |url-status=live}}</ref> J. Aron was involved in the coffee and gold markets, and the former CEO of Goldman, [[Lloyd Blankfein]], joined the firm as a result of this merger.<ref>{{Cite news |title=As rivals fade, Goldman Sachs stands firm on commodities |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2013/12/06/as-rivals-fade-goldman-sachs-stands-firm-on-commodities.html |work=[[CNBC]] |date=December 6, 2013|archive-date=November 29, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201129115336/https://www.cnbc.com/2013/12/06/as-rivals-fade-goldman-sachs-stands-firm-on-commodities.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

In 1983, the firm moved into a newly constructed global headquarters at 85 Broad Street and occupied that building until it moved to its current headquarters in 2009.<ref>{{Cite web |title=85 Broad Street – Goldman Sachs |url=https://www.institutionalinvestor.com/article/b179g8x6qjcf74/85-broad-street---goldman-sachs |access-date=January 9, 2023 |website=Institutional Investor |date=March 12, 2018 |language=en-gb |archive-date=October 3, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221003082029/https://www.institutionalinvestor.com/article/b179g8x6qjcf74/85-broad-street---goldman-sachs |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=December 9, 2009 |title=The House That Goldman Built |url=https://observer.com/2009/12/the-house-that-goldman-built/ |access-date=January 9, 2023 |website=Observer |language=en-US |archive-date=January 9, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230109140105/https://observer.com/2009/12/the-house-that-goldman-built/ |url-status=live }}</ref> In 1985, it underwrote the public offering of the [[real estate investment trust]] that owned [[Rockefeller Center]], then the largest [[Real estate investment trust|REIT]] offering in history.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/business/1995/09/19/pitching-them-high-and-inside-in-the-rockefeller-center-deal/7794b49c-3489-448e-a33c-4d8a691034f6/ |last=Sloan |first=Allan | author-link=Allan Sloan |title=PITCHING THEM HIGH AND INSIDE IN THE ROCKEFELLER CENTER DEAL | newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=September 19, 1995 |issn=0190-8286 |archive-date=February 8, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210208043020/https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/business/1995/09/19/pitching-them-high-and-inside-in-the-rockefeller-center-deal/7794b49c-3489-448e-a33c-4d8a691034f6/|url-status=live}}</ref> In accordance with the beginning of the [[dissolution of the Soviet Union]], the firm also became involved in facilitating the global privatization movement by advising companies that were spinning off from their parent governments.<ref>{{Cite web | last=McCoy| first=Patricia |title=Levers of Law Reform: Public Goods and Russian Banking | url=https://scholarship.law.cornell.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1395&context=cilj | publisher=[[Cornell Law School]] | year=1997 | archive-date=October 22, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201022190041/https://scholarship.law.cornell.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1395&context=cilj |url-status=live}}</ref>

In 1986, the firm formed Goldman Sachs Asset Management, which manages the majority of its mutual funds and [[hedge fund]]s.<ref name=humbled/> In the same year, the firm also underwrote the IPO of [[Microsoft]], advised [[General Electric]] on its acquisition of [[RCA]],<ref name=humbled>{{Cite news | title=Goldman Sachs humbled | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/analysis-and-features/goldman-sachs-humbled-1192852.html | work=[[The Independent]] | date=December 17, 2008 | archive-date=November 16, 2020 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201116055405/https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/analysis-and-features/goldman-sachs-humbled-1192852.html | url-status=live}}</ref> and joined the [[London Stock Exchange|London]] and [[Tokyo stock exchange]]s, where its [[mergers and acquisitions]] grew.<ref name=brief/> During the 1980s, the firm became the first bank to distribute its investment research electronically and created the first public offering of original issue deep-discount [[bond (finance)|bond]].<ref name=humbled/> In 1988, it helped the [[State Bank of India]] obtain a credit rating and issue US$200 million in the US commercial paper market.<ref>{{Cite web | url=https://www.goldmansachs.com/our-firm/history/moments/1994-emerging-markets.html | title=Goldman Sachs Expands its Footprint in Emerging Markets | work=Goldman Sachs}}</ref>

[[Robert Rubin]] and [[Stephen Friedman (PFIAB)|Stephen Friedman]] assumed the co-senior partnership in 1990 and pledged to focus on globalization of the firm to strengthen the merger & acquisition and trading business lines.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-goldman-board-idUSBRE93315P20130404 |title=Former Goldman head Stephen Friedman retires from board |work=[[Reuters]] |date=April 4, 2013 |archive-date=November 3, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201103184956/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-goldman-board-idUSBRE93315P20130404 |url-status=live}}</ref> In 1990, the firm introduced paperless trading to the New York Stock Exchange.<ref>{{Cite web | url=https://www.princeton.edu/~ota/disk2/1990/9015/9015.PDF | title=Electronic Bulls and Bears: U.S. Securities Markets and Information Technology | date=September 1990}}</ref> Rubin left the firm in 1992 to work in the [[Presidency of Bill Clinton]].<ref name=brief/> In 1994, the company launched the [[Goldman Sachs Commodity Index]] (GSCI) and opened its first office in China in [[Beijing]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/03/01/business/goldman-sachs-in-china.html |title=Goldman, Sachs in China |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=March 1, 1994|work=[[The New York Times]] In January 2000, Goldman, along with [[Lehman Brothers]], was the lead manager for the first internet bond offering for the [[World Bank]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|last=Fuerbringer|first=Jonathan|date=January 13, 2000|title=The Markets: Market Place; The bond market, refuge of the instinctually stodgy, is being wired for e-commerce dealing.|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/01/13/business/markets-market-place-bond-market-refuge-instinctually-stodgy-being-wired-for-e.html|access-date=June 10, 2020|issn=0362-4331|archive-date=September 12, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200912163856/https://www.nytimes.com/2000/01/13/business/markets-market-place-bond-market-refuge-instinctually-stodgy-being-wired-for-e.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

In 2000, Goldman Sachs advised Jim and Janet Baker on the sale of [[Dragon NaturallySpeaking]] to [[Lernout & Hauspie]] of Belgium for $580 million in L&H stock. Lawyers for Goldman said it was not Goldman's job to uncover the accounting fraud. On January 23, 2013, a federal jury rejected the Bakers' claims and found Goldman Sachs not liable to the Bakers, instead siding with Goldman in counterclaims.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McLaughlin |first1=Tim |last2=Pressman |first2=Aaron |title=Goldman cleared of all charges in doomed Dragon sale |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-goldman-dragon-trial-idUSBRE90M1GX20130123 | work=[[Reuters]] |date=January 23, 2013|archive-date=January 5, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160105233438/http://www.reuters.com/article/us-goldman-dragon-trial-idUSBRE90M1GX20130123 |url-status=live}}</ref>

=== Subprime mortgage crisis: 2007–2008 ===
As a result of its involvement in securitization during the [[subprime mortgage crisis]], Goldman Sachs suffered during the [[2007–2008 financial crisis]],<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/freeexchange/2009/07/like_everyone_else_goldman_was | title=Like everyone else, Goldman was in trouble | newspaper=[[The Economist]] | date=July 28, 2009 | archive-date=January 25, 2017 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170125161003/http://www.economist.com/blogs/freeexchange/2009/07/like_everyone_else_goldman_was | url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.mcclatchydc.com/news/politics-government/article24561376.html | title=How Goldman secretly bet on the U.S. housing crash | publisher=McClatchy | date=November 1, 2009 | url-access=subscription | archive-date=April 10, 2017 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170410183150/http://www.mcclatchydc.com/news/politics-government/article24561376.html | url-status=live }}</ref> and it received a $10 billion investment from the [[United States Department of the Treasury]] as part of the [[Troubled Asset Relief Program]], a financial [[bailout]] created by the [[Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008]]. The investment was made in November 2008 and was repaid with [[interest]] in June 2009.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/money/economy/2009-04-14-tarp-repay-bank-bailout_N.htm | title=Goldman Sachs to return $10B of bailout money | work=[[USA Today]] | date=April 15, 2009 | archive-date=January 29, 2019 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190129220350/http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/money/economy/2009-04-14-tarp-repay-bank-bailout_N.htm | url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title=JPMorgan and 9 Other Banks Repay TARP Money |url=https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2009/06/17/jpmorgan-repays-treasury-as-tarp-exits-continue/ | issue=DealBook | work=[[The New York Times]] |date=June 17, 2009 |url-access=limited |archive-date=March 10, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190310080912/https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2009/06/17/jpmorgan-repays-treasury-as-tarp-exits-continue/ |url-status=live}}</ref>

During the 2007 [[subprime mortgage crisis]], Goldman profited from the collapse in subprime mortgage bonds in summer 2007 by [[short (finance)|short-selling]] subprime [[Mortgage-backed security|mortgage-backed securities]]. Two Goldman traders, Michael Swenson and [[Josh Birnbaum]], are credited with being responsible for the firm's large profits during the crisis.<ref name="FinancialTimes2010December10AllowayTracy">{{cite news|last1=Alloway|first1=Tracy|title=Goldman's uneasy subprime short|url=https://ftalphaville.ft.com/2010/12/10/433571/goldmans-uneasy-subprime-short/|access-date=June 3, 2012|agency=Nikkei|issue=Alphaville|publisher=Financial Times|date=December 10, 2010|language=en|url-access=subscription|archive-date=September 19, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200919153553/https://ftalphaville.ft.com/2010/12/10/433571/goldmans-uneasy-subprime-short/|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/banksandfinance/2788346/Subprime-star-Josh-Birnbaum-leaves-Goldman.html |title=Subprime star Josh Birnbaum leaves Goldman. ''The Telegraph''. |date=April 17, 2008 |access-date=April 3, 2018 |archive-date=November 22, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201122155522/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/banksandfinance/2788346/Subprime-star-Josh-Birnbaum-leaves-Goldman.html |url-status=live }}</ref> The pair, members of Goldman's [[structured product]]s group in [[New York City]], made a profit of $4 billion by "betting" on a collapse in the subprime market and shorting mortgage-related securities. By summer 2007, they persuaded colleagues to see their point of view and convinced skeptical risk management executives.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2007/dec/21/goldmansachs.useconomy |title=Success shines unwelcome spotlight on to Goldman Sachs |work=The Guardian |date=December 21, 2007 |location=London |first=Andrew |last=Clark |access-date=September 12, 2013 |archive-date=August 1, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200801033416/https://www.theguardian.com/business/2007/dec/21/goldmansachs.useconomy |url-status=live }}</ref> The firm initially avoided large subprime write-downs and achieved a net profit due to significant losses on non-prime [[securitization|securitized]] loans being offset by gains on short mortgage positions. The firm's viability was called into question as the crisis intensified in September 2008.

In October 2007, Goldman Sachs was criticized for packaging risky mortgages and selling them to the public as safe investments.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://fortune.com/2016/04/12/goldman-sachs-house-of-junk-mortgage-bonds/ | title=Goldman Sachs' House of Junk | first=Allan | last=Sloan | author-link=Allan Sloan | publisher=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] | date=October 16, 2007 | access-date=May 18, 2017 | archive-date=November 12, 2020 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201112024930/https://fortune.com/2016/04/12/goldman-sachs-house-of-junk-mortgage-bonds/ | url-status=live }}</ref>

====Firm's response to criticism of AIG payments====
Goldman Sachs maintained that its net exposure to AIG was 'not material', and that the firm was protected by [[hedge (finance)|hedges]] (in the form of CDSs with other counterparties) and $7.5 billion of [[collateral (finance)|collateral]], which would have protected the bank from incurring an economic loss in the event of an AIG bankruptcy or failure.<ref>{{cite news | first=Jordan | last=Terry | url=https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2009/11/the-media-is-wrong-about-goldman-sachs-aig/30565/ | title=The Media is Wrong about Goldman Sachs, AIG | work=[[The Atlantic]] | date=November 20, 2009 | archive-date=September 5, 2017 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170905003149/https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2009/11/the-media-is-wrong-about-goldman-sachs-aig/30565/ | url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://archive.nytimes.com/dealbook.nytimes.com/2009/03/20/goldman-maintains-it-had-no-aig-exposure/ |title=Goldman Maintains It Had No A.I.G. According to a report by the United States Office of the Inspector General of [[Troubled Asset Relief Program|TARP]], if AIG had collapsed, it would have made it difficult for Goldman to liquidate its trading positions with AIG, even at discounts, and it also would have put pressure on other counterparties that "might have made it difficult for Goldman Sachs to collect on the credit protection it had purchased against an AIG default." Finally, the report said, an AIG default would have forced Goldman Sachs to bear the risk of declines in the value of billions of dollars in collateral debt obligations.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.propublica.org/documents/item/30823-sigtarp-initial-report-to-the-congress |title=SIGTARP Initial Report to Congress|last=Barofsky |first=Neil |date=February 6, 2009 |publisher=[[United States Department of Treasury]]}}</ref> Goldman argued that CDSs are [[Mark-to-market|marked to market]] (i.e. valued at their current market price) and their positions netted between counterparties daily. Thus, as the cost of insuring AIG's obligations against default rose substantially in the lead-up to its bailout, the sellers of the CDS contracts had to post more [[Collateral (finance)|collateral]] to Goldman Sachs. The firm claims this meant its hedges were effective and the firm would have been protected against an AIG bankruptcy and the risk of knock-on defaults, had AIG been allowed to fail.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB123967007321015621 |title=Goldman Protected Its Clients From AIG's Weakness |last=van Praag |first=Lucas|date=April 14, 2009 | work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | url-access=subscription}}</ref> However, in practice, the collateral would not protect fully against losses both because protection sellers would not be required to post collateral that covered the complete loss during a bankruptcy and because the value of the collateral would be highly uncertain following the repercussions of an AIG bankruptcy.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.economist.com/free-exchange/2009/04/14/did-we-need-to-bail-out-aig |title=Did we need to bail out AIG? |date=April 14, 2009| newspaper=[[The Economist]]}}</ref>

===Abacus synthetic CDOs and SEC lawsuit===
{{anchor|Abacus CDO}}
{{See also|Merrill Lynch#CDO controversies|Magnetar Capital}}

Unlike many investors and investment bankers, Goldman Sachs anticipated the [[subprime mortgage crisis]].<ref name=Bundled>{{cite news |last1=Morgenson |first1=Gretchen |last2=Story |first2=Louise |title=Banks Bundled Bad Debt, Bet Against It and Won |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/24/business/24trading.html|access-date=April 14, 2010|agency=The New York Times Company |issue=Business|page=A1|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=December 24, 2009 |location=New York|language=en|url-access=limited|archive-date=April 30, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110430022305/http://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/24/business/24trading.html|url-status=live}} (This article describes the intricate links between Goldman Sachs trader, Jonathan M. Egol, synthetic collateralized debt obligations, or C.D.O., ABACUS, and asset-backed securities index (ABX))</ref> Some of its traders became "bearish" on the housing boom beginning in 2004 and developed mortgage-related securities, originally intended to protect Goldman from investment losses in the housing market. In late 2006, Goldman management changed the firm's overall stance on the mortgage market from positive to negative. As the market began its downturn, Goldman "created even more of these securities", no longer just hedging or satisfying investor orders but, according to business journalist [[Gretchen Morgenson]], "enabling it to pocket huge profits" from the mortgage defaults and that Goldman "used the C.D.O.'s to place unusually large negative bets that were not mainly for hedging purposes".<ref name=Bundled/> Authors Bethany McLean and Joe Nocera stated that "the firm's later insistence that it was merely a 'market maker' in these transactions – implying that it had no stake in the economic performance of the securities it was selling to clients – became less true over time"-<ref>{{cite book | author=McLean and Nocera | title=All the Devils Are Here | page=271}}</ref>

The investments were called [[synthetic CDO]]s because unlike regular [[collateralized debt obligation]]s, the principal and interest they paid out came not from mortgages or other loans, but from premiums to pay for insurance against mortgage defaults – the insurance known as "[[credit default swap]]s". Goldman and some other hedge funds held a "short" position in the securities, paying the premiums, while the investors (insurance companies, pension funds, etc.) receiving the premiums were the "long" position. The longs were responsible for paying the insurance "claim" to Goldman and any other shorts if the mortgages or other loans defaulted. Through April 2007, Goldman issued over 20 CDOs in its "Abacus" series worth a total of $10.9 billion (~${{Format price|{{Inflation|index=US-GDP|value=10900000000|start_year=2007}}}} in {{Inflation/year|US-GDP}}).<ref name="NewYorkTimes2010April16StoryLouise">{{cite news |last1=Story|first1=Louise|last2=Morgenson|first2=Gretchen |title=S.E.C. Accuses Goldman of Fraud in Housing Deal |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/17/business/17goldman.html |access-date=January 26, 2014 |agency=The New York Times Company |issue=Business|page=A1 |work=[[The New York Times]]|date=April 16, 2010 |location=New York|language=en |url-access=limited|archive-date=December 22, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131222223130/http://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/17/business/17goldman.html|url-status=live}}</ref> All together Goldman packaged, sold, and shorted a total of 47 synthetic CDOs, with an aggregate face value of $66 billion between July 1, 2004, and May 31, 2007.<ref>''FCIR'' p. 145</ref>

But while Goldman was praised for its foresight, some argued its bets against the securities it created gave it a vested interest in their failure. These securities performed very poorly for the long investors and by April 2010, at least US$5 billion (~${{Format price|{{Inflation|index=US-GDP|value=5000000000|start_year=2010}}}} in {{Inflation/year|US-GDP}}) worth of the securities either carried "junk" ratings or had defaulted.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.smh.com.au/business/world-business/abacus-let-goldman-shuffle-mortgage-risk-like-beads-20100418-smx3.html | title=Abacus Let Goldman Shuffle Mortgage Risk Like Beads | first1=Jody | last1=Shenn | first2=Bob | last2=Ivry | agency=[[Bloomberg News]] | publisher=[[Sydney Morning Herald]] | date=April 16, 2010 | access-date=May 21, 2017 | archive-date=November 8, 2021 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211108131217/https://www.smh.com.au/business/abacus-let-goldman-shuffle-mortgage-risk-like-beads-20100419-smx3.html | url-status=live }}</ref> One CDO examined by critics which Goldman bet against but also sold to investors, was the $800 million (~${{Format price|{{Inflation|index=US-GDP|value=800000000|start_year=2006}}}} in {{Inflation/year|US-GDP}}) Hudson Mezzanine CDO issued in 2006. In the Senate Permanent Subcommittee hearings, Goldman executives stated that the company was trying to remove subprime securities from its books. ====2010 SEC civil fraud lawsuit====
In April 2010, the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] (SEC) charged Goldman Sachs and one of its vice-presidents, Fabrice Tourre, with securities fraud. The SEC alleged that Goldman had told buyers of a [[synthetic CDO]], a type of investment, that the underlying assets in the investment had been picked by an independent CDO manager, ACA Management. In fact, [[Paulson & Co.]] a [[hedge fund]] that wanted to bet against the investment had played a "significant role" in the selection,<ref name="FCIR-p192">''[http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/GPO-FCIC/pdf/GPO-FCIC.pdf Financial Crisis Inquiry Report] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180906112326/https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/GPO-FCIC/pdf/GPO-FCIC.pdf |date=September 6, 2018 }}'', by the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, 2011, p.192</ref> and the package of securities turned out to become "one of the worst-performing mortgage deals of the housing crisis" because "less than a year after the deal was completed, 100% of the bonds selected for Abacus had been downgraded".<ref name="WSJ2010April20LucchettiAaron">{{cite news|last1=Lucchetti|first1=Aaron|last2=Ng|first2=Serena|title=Abacus Deal: As Bad as They Come|journal=The Wall Street Journal. ===Alleged commodity price manipulation===
{{Hatnote|See also: [[2000s commodities boom]]}}

A provision of the 1999 financial deregulation law, the [[Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act]], allows commercial banks to enter into any business activity that is "complementary to a financial activity and does not pose a substantial risk to the safety or soundness of depository institutions or the financial system generally".<ref name=devious>{{cite magazine | last=Taibbi | first=Matt | title=The Vampire Squid Strikes Again: The Mega Banks' Most Devious Scam Yet | magazine=Rolling Stone | date=February 12, 2014 | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/news/the-vampire-squid-strikes-again-the-mega-banks-most-devious-scam-yet-20140212 | access-date=February 14, 2014 | archive-date=February 13, 2014 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140213231325/http://www.rollingstone.com/politics/news/the-vampire-squid-strikes-again-the-mega-banks-most-devious-scam-yet-20140212 | url-status=live }}</ref> Since the passing of the laws, Goldman Sachs and other investment banks such as Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan Chase have branched out into ownership of a wide variety of enterprises including raw materials, such as food products, zinc, copper, tin, nickel and, aluminum.

Some critics, such as [[Matt Taibbi]], believe that allowing a company to both "control the supply of crucial physical commodities, and also trade in the financial products that might be related to those markets", is "akin to letting casino owners who take book on NFL games during the week also coach all the teams on Sundays".<ref name=devious/>

====Goldman Sachs Commodity Index and the 2005–2008 Food Bubble====

====Oil futures speculation====
Investment banks, including Goldman, have also been accused of driving up the price of [[gasoline]] by speculating on the oil [[futures exchange]]. The presence of positions by investment banks on the market was significant for the fact that the banks have deep pockets, and so the means to significantly sway prices, and unlike traditional market participants, neither produced oil nor ever took physical possession of actual barrels of oil they bought and sold. ===Improper securities lending practices===
In January 2016, Goldman Sachs agreed to pay $15 million after it was found that a team of Goldman employees, between 2008 and 2013, "granted locates" by arranging to borrow securities to settle short sales without adequate review. However, U.S. regulation for short selling requires brokerages to enter an agreement to borrow securities on behalf of customers or to have "reasonable grounds" for believing that it can borrow the security before entering contracts to complete the sale. ==Political contributions==
According to [[OpenSecrets]], Goldman Sachs and its employees collectively gave $3.3 million in the [[2022 United States elections]] to various candidates, [[leadership PAC]]s, political parties, [[527 group]]s, and outside spending entities benefiting both major American political parties.
